definition: The 'ultimate superior things' or prime matter in medieval cosmography and alchemy.
The practice of using hidden powers within nature, as discussed by Agrippa.
[Practitioner] 3rd-century Gnostic alchemist, author of the earliest known alchemical texts.
[Practitioner] 8th-century Persian polymath, credit for the sulphur-mercury theory.
[Practitioner] Legendary founder of Hermeticism and alchemy, associated with the Emerald Tablet.
[Practitioner] Renaissance physician and alchemist, founder of iatrochemistry (Tria Prima).
[Practitioner] English physician and alchemist, noted for his encyclopedic Hermetic works.
[Practitioner] German alchemist and physician to Rudolf II, author of Atalanta Fugiens.
[Practitioner] English polymath and advisor to Elizabeth I, author of Monas Hieroglyphica.
[Practitioner] Welsh alchemist and priest, wrote under the pseudonym Eugenius Philalethes.
[Practitioner] 14th-century French scribe and legendary alchemist associated with the Stone.
[Practitioner] Paracelsian physician and chemist, author of Basilica Chymica.
[Text] Foundational Hermetic text containing the dictum 'As above, so below'.
[Text] High-Renaissance alchemical manuscript known for its 22 elaborate miniatures.
[Text] The 'Silent Book', an alchemical treatise composed of plates without text.
[Text] 15th-century manuscript attributed to Thomas Aquinas, rich in allegories.
[Text] 16th-century treatise illustrating the conjunction of King and Queen.
[Text] Symbolic work by John Dee explaining a single hieroglyphic sign.
[Text] Emblem book by Michael Maier combining alchemy, music, and myth.
[Text] One of the oldest Latin alchemical texts, framed as a council of philosophers.
[Text] The 'Fountain of Life', significant Neoplatonic-alchemical influence.
[Substance] One of the Tria Prima; represents the spirit or volatile principle.
[Substance] One of the Tria Prima; represents the soul or flammable principle.
[Substance] One of the Tria Prima; represents the body or fixed principle.
[Substance] Mineral often called the 'Grey Wolf' used in the purification of gold.
[Substance] Sulphuric acid, associated with the acronym VITRIOL (Visita Interiora Terrae...).
[Substance] A mixture of nitric and hydrochloric acids capable of dissolving gold.
[Substance] Bright red mineral (mercury sulphide), a primary source of mercury.
[Substance] Universal solvent or 'Mercury of the Philosophers', alpha and omega.
[Substance] The purified, non-vulgar mercury required for the Magnum Opus.
[Substance] The Philosopher's Stone, the goal of the Great Work.
[Allegory] Symbol of a serpent eating its own tail, representing cyclical nature.
[Allegory] Allegory for a corrosive acid or the initial raw state of mercury.
[Allegory] Represents the fixed principle or the completion of the Rubedo stage.
[Allegory] Represents the volatile principle or the Albedo stage.
[Allegory] The 'Great Work' of creating the Philosopher's Stone.
[Allegory] The 'Blackening' stage, representing putrefaction and death.
[Allegory] The 'Reddening' stage, representing the final goal.
[Apparatus] The furnace used by alchemists to maintain a constant heat.
[Apparatus] A tool for distillation, consisting of two vessels and a tube.
[Apparatus] A circulatory distillation vessel with two side arms.
[Apparatus] The lower part of a still, often shaped like a gourd.
[Apparatus] The process of heating a substance to high temperatures to oxidize it.
[Apparatus] The separation of substances based on differences in volatility.
[Apparatus] The transition of a substance from solid to gas phase directly.
[Apparatus] The process of thickening or solidifying a liquid.
[Apparatus] Continuous distillation where the distillate returns to the base.
[Apparatus] The union of opposites (King and Queen) in the alchemical process.
[Practitioner] 13th-century physician and alchemist, attributed with many works on the Stone.
[Practitioner] Major figure in medieval logic and alchemy (though much is pseudo-Lullian).
[Practitioner] Legendary 15th-century monk and alchemist, author of The Twelve Keys.
[Practitioner] English alchemist and canon, author of The Compound of Alchymy.
[Practitioner] Pseudonym for an influential 17th-century alchemist, likely George Starkey.
[Practitioner] Colonial American alchemist and physician, tutor to Robert Boyle.
[Practitioner] Natural philosopher and alchemist, key figure in the transition to chemistry.
[Practitioner] Physicist who spent decades studying alchemy and translating the Emerald Tablet.
[Practitioner] Early alchemist (1st-3rd century) credited with inventing the bain-marie.
[Practitioner] Early Egyptian alchemist, associated with the Chrysopoeia.
[Practitioner] Early alchemist often associated with the discovery of arsenic.
[Practitioner] Legendary Persian magus and alchemist mentioned by Pliny.
[Practitioner] Greek alchemist (c. 200 BC), author of Physika kai Mystika.
[Practitioner] Chinese alchemist (2nd century), author of the Cantong qi.
[Practitioner] Chinese alchemist and Taoist, author of the Baopuzi.
[Practitioner] Persian physician and alchemist, characterized by his empirical approach.
[Practitioner] Influential philosopher-physician who examined the possibility of transmutation.
[Practitioner] Medieval scholar and theologian with significant alchemical attributions.
[Practitioner] English philosopher and Franciscan friar, interested in experimental science and alchemy.
[Practitioner] 14th-century alchemist, author of the Margarita Pretiosa Novella.
[Practitioner] English alchemist and correspondent with Pope John XXII.
[Practitioner] 15th-century Italian alchemist dedicated to the search for the Stone.
[Practitioner] German physician and Paracelsian alchemist, author of Amphitheatrum Sapientiae Eternae.
[Practitioner] German physician and chemist, author of Alchymia.
[Practitioner] Salt-maker and publisher of the works of Basil Valentine.
[Practitioner] Polish alchemist and diplomat, developer of the 'nitric' theory of life.
[Practitioner] French counselor and alchemist, author of Arcanum Hermeticae Philosophiae.
[Practitioner] Son of John Dee, alchemist and physician to Czar Michael I.
[Practitioner] 19th-century author of A Suggestive Inquiry into the Hermetic Mystery.
[Practitioner] Psychologist who analyzed alchemical symbolism and its relation to the psyche.
[Practitioner] Psychoanalyst who linked alchemical symbolism with psychic phenomena.
[Practitioner] Historian of religion who explored the mythic dimensions of metallurgy and alchemy.
[Practitioner] Modern historian of science focusing on the reality of alchemical practice.
[Practitioner] Modern historian of science known for work on George Starkey and deck-making.
[Practitioner] Modern scholar focusing on Paracelsianism in early modern France.
[Practitioner] Modern historian focusing on the social and legal aspects of alchemy.
[Practitioner] Modern historian focusing on the material culture of alchemy and science.
[Practitioner] Modern scholar focusing on the patronage systems of alchemists.
[Practitioner] Historian known for her work on the Hermetic tradition and the 'Rosicrucian Enlightenment'.
[Practitioner] Renowned German scholar of early modern alchemical literature.
[Text] Early Greek alchemical papyrus focused on the production of gold.
[Text] Ancient Egyptian recipe book for metallurgical imitations.
[Text] Companion to the Leyden Papyrus, focused on dyeing and gemstones.
[Text] The 'Secret of Secrets', a medieval mirror for princes with alchemical sections.
[Text] Influential treatise describing the steps of the Great Work.
[Text] Large illustrated scroll depicting the alchemical process according to George Ripley.
[Text] 17th-century collection of Hermetic and alchemical works.
[Text] Elias Ashmole's collection of English alchemical poetry.
[Text] Mary Anne Atwood's 19th-century work on the psychological mystery of alchemy.
[Text] C.G. Jung's foundational work on alchemical symbolism.
[Text] Ge Hong's masterwork on Taoist alchemy and immortality.
[Text] The 'Kinship of the Three', the oldest known Chinese alchemical text.
[Text] Influential Latin alchemical work likely written by Paul of Taranto.
[Text] The 'New Precious Pearl' by Petrus Bonus.
[Text] Oswald Croll's pharmaceutical and alchemical textbook.
[Text] Heinrich Khunrath's masterpiece of alchemical mysticism.
[Text] Treatise by Basil Valentine on the medicinal use of antimony.
[Text] Andreas Libavius's systematization of chemical knowledge.

[Substance] The most perfect metal, representing the sun and immortality.
[Substance] The second most perfect metal, representing the moon and the soul.
[Substance] Base metal associated with the planet Venus.
[Substance] Base metal associated with the planet Mars.
[Substance] Base metal associated with the planet Saturn, representing the Nigredo.
[Substance] Base metal associated with the planet Jupiter.
[Substance] Potent poison used as a whitening agent in alchemical metallurgy.
[Substance] Ammonium chloride, essential for many alchemical distillations.
[Substance] Potassium nitrate, central to late alchemical theories of life.
[Substance] Concentrated ethanol obtained by distillation, used as a solvent.
[Allegory] The union of opposites, often depicted as a royal marriage.
[Allegory] The sealed vessel in which the alchemical transformation occurs.
[Allegory] The 'little man' created through alchemical or magical means.
[Allegory] The three principles: Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury.
[Allegory] The 'Two-Thing', a hermaphroditic figure representing the end of the work.
[Allegory] The display of many colors during the alchemical process.
[Allegory] The closed loop of the alchemical vessel and the process itself.
[Allegory] Symbol of self-sacrifice and nourishment of the work.
[Allegory] Symbol of rebirth and the attainment of the Red Stone.
[Allegory] The process of making a volatile substance stable.
[Apparatus] Basic tools used for grinding and mixing solid materials.
[Apparatus] Heat-resistant container used for melting metals.
[Apparatus] A glass vessel with a long, downward-pointing neck used for distillation.
[Apparatus] A double boiler used for gentle, uniform heating.
[Apparatus] The breakdown of organic or alchemical matter, often the first stage.
[Apparatus] The stage where the Stone is infused with vitality and power.
[Apparatus] Increasing the quantity and quality of the Philosopher's Stone.
[Apparatus] The final act of using the Stone to transmute base metals into gold.
[Apparatus] A method of heating a vessel using hot sand for even temperatures.
[Apparatus] Similar to a sand bath, but using ashes for gentler heat.
